title: leo mckinstry schools reopening militant teaching unions
story: After the long summer holidays, it signies hope at the chance of fresh beginnings and excitement at the prospect of change.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNext week, the new term will have greater meaning than ever for pupils, professionals and parents. At last, after an unprecedented lockdown of six months, all schools are due to re-open, representing a giant leap back towards normality. But the damage caused by the Coronavirus disruption has been severe.Many parents have been prevented from ing to work. Young people’s education has been badly undermined, especially because the quality of online learning has been so uneven. One study found that a fth of pupils had less than an hour’s instruction a day. Moreover, social activities and friendships – which are a vital part of growing up – have been heavily restricted.The exam chaos over the last fortnight was a fitting symbol of the vacuum created by the absence of proper schooling. No advanced society canwhen a vital sector like education is temporarily paralysed. That is why it is so important that the Government succeeds in its goal of seeing a fullto the classroom. As Boris Johnson put it at the weekend, “it is vital for pupils’ education. It is vital for their welfare. It’s vital for their physical and, indeed, mental well-being.”Given the Government’s mixed record on its management of the Covid crisis, this will be a big test. From the inadequate supply of protective gear to the botched imposition of quarantine rules, Ministers have got it badly wrong at times. They cannot afford another fiasco next week.But to do that, they will have to curtail the influence of militant teaching unions, which thrive in a climate of scare-mongering and grievance. Full of negativity, these hardened left-wing operators turn every pebble of dficulty into a giant boulder of obstruction. They are the abominable no men and women, the ultimate “can’t do” brigade.To overcome the unions’ capacity for trouble-making, reassurances about safety will be absolutely crucial. Most teachers are keen to go back to work, but they want to know schools will not be dangerous environments. That is why the recent upbeat advice from medical experts has been so welcome. It is clear from the Covid experience around the world that not only are children less likely to transmit the disease than any other group, but also that schools are safer than most other workplaces. Yesterday, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries pointed out that a child is more likely to be involved in a traffic accident or die from flu than to be harmed by Coronavirus.That message was also spelt out by her boss Chris Whitty, who said on Sunday that the damage to health caused by a continued schools lockdown is potentially greater than the impact of Covid. “The balance of risk is very strongly in favour of children going to school,” he declared, adding the chances of catching the disease “are incredibly small.” In fact, there is now hard evidence to prove this. Although the vast majority of schools were closed since March, over one million pupils – such as the children of essential workers – went back to the classroom in June. Yet a comprehensive study by Public Health England showed that in the subsequent weeks until the end of term, just  children and  staff tested positive for Covid- – and nearly all these infections occurred outside the school. There were hardly any cases of children passing on the disease to each other, or to their teachers. Other research from around the world has come to the same conclusion.But none of this seems to matter to the teaching unions, eager to exploit anxiety in pursuit of their anti-Tory agenda. These are the organisations which for decades have blocked every major reform of the education system and have defended every outdated working practice. With depressing inevitability, they have continually put their own narrow interests before the wider needs of pupils. They want the respect due to trained professionals but they frequently display the rebellious spirit of the permanent agitators. “Strike action is a very powerful tool,” said Amanda Martin, the President of the ,-strong National Education Unionin an interview with the Communist Morning Star newspaper in , adding, “I’ve run demos and rallies and worked with trade councils to bring everyone out and that’s brilliant.”Led by the NEU, the unions have brought the same attitude to the Coronavirus crisis. Instead of looking for solutions, they have endlessly exaggerated problems. One Whitehall insider says of Dr Mary Bousted, the £,-a-year joint general secretary of the NEU, “it’s all about the union, to hell with the teachers who want to get back into the classroom – let alone the children.” A left-wing radical, Bousted jokes that the word “strike” was one of the first she learnt as a child. Hers is not the voice of co-operation and enterprise, so it is hardly surprising that the Government has struggled to get schools reopened.In June, a planned majorwas thwarted by the unions, dealing a severe blow to Gavin Williamson’s credibility. One left-wing website gushed that the continued shutdown was due “to the hard work of NEU branch secretaries and rank and file militants galvanising the members.” In the months since, an alliance of unions – including Bousted’s NEU and Unite led by the notorious Merseyside militant Len McCluskey – have fought a y battle against a swt re-opening. Central to this effort at sabotage was a vast -point checklist of detailed questions which the Department for Education was told it had to answer. Dubbed by critics “a wreckers’ charter”, the list included queries such as “will lidded bins with double bagging be available in every classroom”, “will dedicated space be available for any breastfeeding women to express milk” and “has behaviour policy been reviewed to acknowledge the increased level of trauma and anxiety experienced by pupils ” Some Tories complained that the union was playing politics. Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Education Select Committee was amazed at the warped priorities: “It is incredible that not one of these nit-picking questions asks the most important thing of all – what’s best for the kids ”Even as September approaches, the whining and resistance has not ceased. “The unions need to stand firm and protect their members,” argues socialist teacher Martin Powell-Davies. In the latest ruse, the public sector outfit UNISON not only wants its members to wear masks in the classroom – something for which there is no scientic evidence of any need – but also to have extra funding for deep cleaning. “Schools need more money to pay for specially trained cleaners, rather than relying on other staff who are busy enough already,” says Jon Richards, UNISON’s head of education. The moan about over-stretched budgets is a favourite of the union movement but it is an empty accusation. The Government is pouring an extra £. billion into education, while this summer it was announced that teachers’ pay is to go up by an average of . per cent, a bigger increase than any other public sector workers received.But that did nothing to stop the combination of whingeing and shroud-waving. The mentality of the hardliners was embodied in a recent statement from the NEU’s far left “Education Solidarity Network” which set out a series of demands to “make sure safety comes first.” Among them were: “smaller class sizes to allow adequate physical distancing” arrangements “for rotas and home learning to be produced in consultation with parents” “local risk assessments to include staggered outdoor breaks, sanitising, provision of transparent coverings to enable access to lip reading and facial expression” and “weekly onsite testing of staff”. Above all, the Network called for extra funding “to implement these measures.” If there were any question of a risk to safety, the union should “prepare for a national strike ballot.”That was so typical. This lot seem to feel more comfortable on the picket line than in the classroom. The Solidary Network might be seen as extreme, but its carping outlook runs right through the unionYesterday, the NEU’s joint general secretary was bleating on the airwaves about the risks of new Covid spikes: “Staff, parents and pupils are being sorely let down by the government because of a lack of a Plan B and of ensuring robust track and trace is in place throughout the country. We believe the Government is negligent in the extreme.” The charge of negligence might be applied with more force to the NEU, whose hostile stance has made thesuch an exhausting obstacle course. The militants cannot be allowed to prevail next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we need to return high street jane moore
story: Having sex was virtually impossible, because by the time we’d removed them we had fallen asleep with exhaustion.Now, jeans come in all shapes and sizes and — hallelujah — streeeeeeetch where necessary to accommodate our lumps and bumps.However, it’s imperative to try before you buyyou want to find the perfect pair and, thanks to lockdown, I found myself shopping for jeans, and other clothes — online.The results prove why we simply mustn’t allow our struggling High Street clothes shops to vanish without trace.I’m usually a size , but am now sporting a bread-baby after lock- down so decided to play safe by ordering a size bigger. Pictured is, apparently, a pair of “size ” jeans from online giant Asosin front of my old size sI couldn’t get them up one leg and, quite frankly, Kate Moss would struggle too. So they’re going back.Then a beguiling ad for summer dresses popped up on my Instagram account and I clicked through to a site called “Cinderear” showing a wide range of very pretty frocks on tanned and shapely models.I ordered what was described as a “Printed Folding Holiday Swing Dress” in what looked like an airy cotton, cinched in at the waist with a brown leather belt. The colour was described as apricot.What arrived — several weeks later — was a beyond-hideous sartorial aberration that was “Made in China” , out of a paper-thin polyester that would make me think twice about standing near a naked flame.What’s more, the colour was more camel and blue than “apricot”, it swamped me, and the brown belt in the photo was nowhere to be seen.It cost me  — approx £ — and the s policy is so ­unintelligible that it’s not worth the bother. More fool me.Buying a bookshelf or bog brush online is fine, but clothes is another matter. I like to feel the fabric and see the fit.So a couple of weeks ago, I masked up and ventured out on a shopping trip to West London’s vast Westfield where I felt like a ­Hollywood superstar having a ­personal shopping experience. It was am on a Monday morning and virtually empty.Little wonder when the ­government guidance says retailers must “discourage customers from handling products while browsing, and keep fitting rooms closed”.One store let me try on a dress then sanitised the cubicle afterwards, another told me thatI tried something on they would have to then take it off display for  hours.In LK Bennett, the fitting rooms were closed and I askedI could try on a blouse over my clothes, just to seeit actually fits. No, they said, you have to buy the item, take it home to try it on, then bring it backit doesn’t fit. Needless to say, I ed home empty-handed.So,our High Street clothes shops are to survive the pandemic, two things need to happen.Unless classed as vulnerable, those of us who actually enjoy clothes ­shopping need to get back out there as soon as possible and actively support them. And the Government needs to relax its strict rules and let retailers and shoppers take inidual responsibility for what happens in store.If I have to wear a mask and gloves to try on a pair of jeans in a cubicle, then I’m happy to do so. I’ll even wipe it down afterwards with my newly repurposed “apricot” dress.SPORTED by the likes of Chris Waddle back in the day, the mullet is apparently enjoying a resurgence during the pandemic.Oh dear. Now barbers have reopened, let’s hope the trend proves short-lived for the naff hairdo that was once described in a dictionary as: “Short at the front, long at the back and ridiculous all round.”FORMER Ukip leader Henry Bolton became embroiled in a scandal after leaving his third we for the charms of party supporter Jo Marney.Now, three years on, that relationship is also over. The reasons why are unclear, but Ms Marney, , says that aside from going on long walks and cosying up in country pubs, they “argued about the finer points of EU legislation”.Ah yes, that should do it.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not feature in TV drama The Crown because there’s not “enough distance” from their story, says the show’s creator Peter Morgan.Also, their le is so outlandish that the series would fall under the category of reality show rather than drama.VINNIE JONES – the “hardman” of football – is seeing a psychologist three times a week after losing we Tanya to cancer.“I would recommend going to see a psychologist  per cent,” he says.“You’re not lying down on a couch asyou’re some lunatic or serial killer. Blokes don’t want to talk about it.“They’ll talk about the girl they slept with last night but won’t go and talk to a doctor about how they’re feeling.”He’s right, and with men accounting for  per cent of all suicides in the UK, it’s never been more important for men like Vinnie to convey that showing vulnerability isn’t a weakness – it’s an admirable strength.CLAUDIA SCHIFFER turned  on tuesday and says she has “never felt more confident or happy”.She adds that she embraces “now” and: “I don’t try to look or feel younger.”She doesn’t need to really, does she ELECTRIC car maker Tesla is developing a sensor that will detecta child has been left unattended in a hot car.Don’t we have those already They’re called parents.LIFE’S precious silences are few and far between. And when you’re PM, one can imagine they are practically non-existent.Particularly as, the ­second you step into the privacy of your own home, there’s a baby with no “on-off” switch.So Boris’s holiday tent – pitched a hundred yards away from his rented cottage on the Scottish coastline – intrigues me. Was it an escape for him alone to snatch a few hours of quiet reflection Or was it a chance for him and Carrie to have noisy sex away from the baby and ever-present bodyguards THE top dream jobs for school leavers are app or games developer and social media influencer.If kids don’t get back to school pronto, that’s all they’ll be able to do.NO ONE begrudges ­politicians a holiday – ­particularly during a ­parliamentary recess.But when you’re an Education minister, you have one job – to be around when the ordure inevitably hits the fan over A-level results being randomly downgraded by an algorithm.Yet not only did Gillian Keegan book a trip abroad, she actually posted a photo from the French Alps on results day – when countless students saw their future plans evaporate. Duh.She also decided to stay there after the quarantine rules came into force – meaning she will have to self-isolate at home for a fortnight on her .But hey ho she’s a taxpayer-funded civil servant so she’s comfortablein the knowledge that, unlike the self-employed, she won’t be losing any pay.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc does not represent britain
story: It is clear from its news, its commentary, its dramas and its dismal, lazy comedy that it despises the voting majority which — to the out-of-touch corporation’s disbelief — repeatedly backed both Brexit and the Tories.Its decision now to censor Rule, ­Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory ought to be the last straw.Boris Johnson has rightly joined many others in condemning it. And though it is not for the PM to decide the BBC’s output, his Government can and should end its publicly funded financial model.The Beeb could turn this around. It just doesn’t want to. It dislikes much about Britain and is ashamed of our past.Its woke staff are interested only in causes and ideas beloved of middle-class metropolitan Remainer graduates like them. Mainstream views shared by the ordinary majority, older Conservative voters in particular, are held in contemptthey are considered at all.So Tories, who won a huge election mandate only months ago, are treated with cynical disdain. Meanwhile ­left-wing activists are routinely given s on news programmes where they masquerade as “ordinary people” or even Newsnight journalists.The BBC has destroyed the case for its licence fee. title: tories wore frank spencer benny crossroads
story: A magnicent record to behold. I cannot remember any government being so devoid of direction, leadership, policy, conviction and — frankly — intelligence.And I had to endure Ted Heath AND John Major’s attempts to run the country. Oh, and the shaft of glorious sunshine that was Gordon Brown. Those guys have nothing on Boris. He is the clear leader in the field. If you ever wanted to know what a country would look likeit was led by Frank Spencer, here you go. Yes, I know — I’m showing my age. To be honest, under this administration I’m feeling my age.For those who don’t remember, Frank was a bumbling, dithering, halfwit from the s sitcom Some Mothers Do ’Ave ’Em. The only dference with Bojo is that Frank was thinner. And, mercully, a fictional creation. Boris is all too real. Many kids will be going back to school wearing face masks. For ages, this government insisted that they would not have to do so. Now they’ve changed their minds. Face masks and grouped in “bubbles”. Probably getting only about half of their usual education,that. Any kid who coughs will be pounced upon, exiled to the Outer Hebrides and the entire school shuts down. Never mind that there has been no recorded case of a schoolkid passing on the virus to a teacher.Never mind that our economy needs the schools fully open with a proper, normal, timetable, so people can get back to work.After six months of no lessons , the kids now have to endure insufferable conditions at school.This is because Boris and the rest have proved utterly incapable of standing up to the teaching unions .Other U-turns have involved the wearing of masks in shops, the usefulness of masks in general, whether there’s any point in closing our borders, the schools due to re-open in June, the scrapping of an expensive track and trace system, the re-grading of GCSEs and A levels . . . oh lordy, the list goes on and on.Sometimes the U-turn appears only a day after the original decision.Sometimes we have to wait a week or so. But come they surely do, a long parade of staggering ineptitude. In fact, I think even Frank Spencer would have been more decisive. Maybe the right comparison is with Benny from Crossroads. Yes, it’s my age again. For those who don’t know, Benny was a cast-iron moron.We know that dealing with this horrible pandemic can’t have been easy. We know Boris has had a dficult year.But the utter lack of planning and resolve has been astonishing. Slow to take the virus seriously, bizarrely refusing to close our airports at the peak of the outbreak, hopelessly lost over track and trace and what do with our poor kids.This has been mismanagement on an almost heroic level. My guess is that Boris will not survive as Prime Minister: His party will get shot of him when the opportunity arises. Because here’s the crucial, damaging question.Could Jeremy Corbyn have handled this crisis any worse I DON’T think those smug monkeys at the BBC realised the fury they would unleash when they banned singing our favourite anthems at The Last Night Of The Proms.A petition reached , names in just  hours.And Dame Vera Lynn is suddenly at No in the iTunes chart with Land Of Hope And Glory.The BBC apparently agreed with the Finnish conductor, Dalia Stasevska, that the “jingoistic” words of Land Of Hope And Glory and Rule Britannia would not be heard this year.I wonder what convinced Ms Stasevska to agree to conduct an evening of patriotic songs when she hates patriotic songs Money, you would guess. Meanwhile another BBC bureaucrat, Cat Lewis, likened singing the songs to Nazis singing about gas chambers.Silly woman. The BBC – its entire staff – has no understanding of the British people. It despises them. Support for the corporation is at an all-time low. And yet the BBC is still up to its tricks. Pulling off the unusual feat of being already in a coffin, but reaching out somehow to hammer more nails into its own lid.A TEAM of British scientists has been studying dreams and what they mean.And they’ve discovered they mean sod all. They are just a continuation of memories from the previous day.Other recent studies showed the same thing. So,you dream you’re flying around your house with some bats, it means you were probably thinking about bats when you were awake.It doesn’t mean you’re neurotic or sexually repressed. So – that’s all the work of Sigmund Freud in the bin. It can go in a black bin liner along with the idiocies put forward by that other drongo of the th Century, Karl Marx. But given that we know all this, why are there still psychoanalysts plying their trade  Is it just to give Britain’s couch-makers plenty of work ANOTHER stupid, virtue-signalling British firm has run into trouble.Avanti West Coast made a big fuss about its new “pride train”, which runs from London to Manchester.The engine is painted in the colours of the LGBT rainbow flag.And it has the word “Pride” written in big letters – just in case anyone doesn’t get the message. There have been thousands of angry comments on social media.My favourite was from John James McGivern: “As a gay man, I don’t want a ‘pride train’, I just want to get on a train that runs on time like everyone .” Quite. Well said.Every time companies pull a stunt like this, the nation cringes.I don’t want a bloody voucher. You cancel the train I’m booked on, then refund the ticket.So I complain to them and they say nothing we can do.So I complain some more and tell them they’re acting illegally.Bingo – money back! I know a lot of people have had similar problems with airlines cancelling their flights and offering “vouchers”.It pays to pester these buggers. Pester and pester until they give in.POOR old slabhead, then. Manchester United’s Harry Maguire found himself uttering the most stupid words in the English language.“Do you know who I am ” And then explained to the Greek police officers who had arrested him that he was “very rich”. Then he tried to bribe them.⚠️Click here for the latest news on Harry MaguireGod help us all.I have always admired Maguire’s heading ability.It now seems to me that he gets so much force behind each header because he has reinforced concrete between his ears. Footballers are not renowned for being terribly bright.But Maguire has lowered the bar still further.One of the problems is the one to which the footballer alluded. He has too much money. So much that he doesn’t know what to do with it.And as a result is completely insulated from the real world. And when he does venture out into the real world it is to be continually abused by halfwits who do not like the club he plays for.Say sorry to the Greeks, Harry. And then shut up and play football.Andlouts give you abuse in the street, just smile at them.CHILDREN from working families were much better behaved during lockdown, according to a study from three British universities.I know that will come as news to some of you.A lot of kids seemed to be climbing the walls out of sheer boredom. But the researchers found that the kids had fewer tantrums. And their concentration improved, too.Maybe we should have a lockdown every year.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: So it is depressing that so many major firms have no plans to order a .⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSome are prioritising workers’ health, though the Covid risk now looks tiny.Some are just delighted to cut costs.But we fear they are complacent about the long-term impact. We suspect that productivity and innovation will nosee.Meanwhile other firms reliant on commuters — coffee shops, sandwich bars, dry cleaners — are staring into the abyss.The Government needs to help them survive and get the bigger companies to encourage a flexibleto the office.First they must enforce it in Whitehall.THRILLING news for the three per cent of Sun readers who vote Lib Dem. Today you’ll finally have a new leader.What titans the candidates are!There’s Sir Ed Davey, who boasts of being first to demand a new Brexit extensionand a Covid public inquiry .He’s the defeated “People’s Vote” bore who, er, “knows how to win”.Layla Moran, meanwhile, hopes to drag the party far to the left of Labour. A suicidal strategy in English Lib Dem seats, not least her own.Does anyone know why the Libs still exist  We’re not even sure these two do.ANY hope that “staycations” might offset the collapse in foreign tourists looks lost.We face a £billion shortfall this year. Worst-hit is London, a virtual ghost town reliant on overseas visitors.These catastrophic figures threaten a tsunami of lost jobs.But our plummeting Covid casualties should no longer be a deterrent. The sledgehammer of quarantine is. title: nora quoirin bedroom window broken sniffer dog
story: The British teen, , who had mental and physical disabilities, vanished from her bedroom at the Dusun Resort in the Malaysian jungle last year.Her naked body was found ten days later on August title: black lives matter mural los angeles permanent hollywood
story: In June, City Councilman Mitch OFarrell stopped crews from removing the colorful mural on the famed strip just as they began painting on the street.Now, its becoming a permanent symbol on the iconic street after it was passed by the city council on August .The bouled between Highland Avenue and Orange Drive will be shut down all week as crews install a permanent mural in honor of the Black Lives Matter movement.This one-block stretch includes the iconic TCL Chinese Theatre and El Capitan Theatre.We had a once-in-a-generation moment this weekend in Hollywood as tens of thousands gathered for a peaceful demonstration on one of the most recognizable bouleds in America, O’Farrell said in a statement, referring to a June  march when crews attempted to remove the mural.We now have a chance to memorialize the movement in a meaningful way. title: chinas missiles south china sea military clash us
story: Fears are growing that the act could embolden hawks on both sides as China launched its powerful Dongfeng missiles into disputed territory on Wednesday. China launched the missiles - including the “aircraft-carrier killers” DF-B and DF-D - title: dan wootton bbc newsnight bias
story: IF there was any doubt the BBC is a blundering, woke mess of an organisation, no longer fit for purpose, then the last seven days should have changed your mind.As  per cent of the country reacted in fury to liberal snobs in London deciding singing Rule, Britannia! or Land Of Hope and Glory makes us backward racists who tacitly approve of slavery, the corporation’s own news broadcasts virtually ignored the unholy row.And that’s the real crux: The BBC no longer reports the real news of the UK, it tries to shape it.What do the -reading, quinoa- munching vegans of London’s Islington THINK we should care about  And what do they BELIEVE happened Forget opinion polls and ignore facts on the ground, but listen to extremist lobby groups and the woketopians who spend all day outraging each other on Twitter.Outgoing Director-General Tony Hall — the man who oversaw the BBC as it completely missed the result of the Brexit referendum and the rise and rise of Boris Johnson — this week claimed the corporation can be the voice of the British public.He doesn’t understand that under his tenure he has lost control of the Beeb’s biased news service.Take Newsnight, now a rogue, partisan operation that represents everything that’s wrong about the BBC.The nightly news show is shamelessly out of touch, moronically preachy and totally hypocritical. As a result, very few people watch it — but it’s the toast of Beeb journos and left-wing social media, giving it undeserved influence over our daily news agenda.Despite her dressing-down over that outrageous Dominic Cummings monologue, Emily Maitlis is considered untouchable by executives. No one dares warn her that constant unbalanced questioning of Tory politicians and right-wing commentators is putting the very future of the Beeb under threat.And then there’s Lewis Goodall, the left-wing operative turned Newsnight policy editor who last week was allowed to author a feature for the New Statesman magazine headlined: “Failed. title: who alexandre dumas google doodle
story: Dumas is one of the most widely read French authors of all time.Dumas Davy de la Pailleterie was born in  in Villers-Cotterêts, France. He later took the name Alexandre Dumas.As a child, Dumas was entertained with stories about his father’s exploits as a general, some of which found their way into his most famous works.Many of Dumass historical books were originally published as serials, including The Count of Monte Cristo, The Three Musketeers, Twenty Years After, and The Vicomte of Bragelonne: Ten Years Later. Today these works have made him one of the most popular French authors in the world, and his books have been translated into over  languages.His novels have also been adapted into nearly  films.Dumas moved to Paris in  and became an accomplished playwright.He also wrote a number of magazine articles and travel books.In the s, Dumas founded the Théâtre Historique in Paris.In the late s, a long-lost Dumas novel was uncovered in Paris’ National Library of France. title: dr hilary jones covid or school bug
story: Most childrento school next week and, in winter, people huddle together indoors for warmth.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey are in closer contact, while windows and doors are closed and provide less ventilation.Social bubbles are more compact and intimate — the perfect breeding ground for bugs to develop.So this winter it is not just Covid- we have to contend with — there are also the usual suspects such as the common cold, flu, asthma, meningitis and bronchitis.But how do you tell the dferences between Covid- and these other bugs Many experts are deeply concerned that with a likely resurgence of Covid- this winter, the double or triple whammy of having any of these other ailments as well could poleaxe people with a confusing array of overlapping symptoms.A cough or sneeze from a harmless common cold can easily transmit Covid-that person is carrying it and does not know. Meanwhile, the germs usually responsible for worsening attacks of bronchitis, pneumonia or chronic lung disease can cause symptoms similar to Covid-, making accurate diagnosis and correct treatment much more dficult.But there is no need for people to panic.Admissions to hospital and mortality related to Covid- are declining.There were only  admissions on Wednesday, while just  new Covid deaths were reported yesterday.That compares to around  or more deaths per day during the peak of the pandemic, at the end of April.Testing is also improving. More than , tests were processed yesterday and it is vital that testing and tracing continues.There is no room at all for complacency.Test-and-trace will tell us exactly what it is that we are dealing with.But it is now more important than ever to know the dferences between the ious winter infections that might come our way. It is easy to panic, thinking we might have coronavirus when it is merely a cold.Equally, we could easily miss the chance of early treatment for Covid-we ignore its earliest symptoms.Millions of people will suffer this winter from sore throats, norovirus, influenza sinusitis, ear infections, allergies, conjunctivitis, ­­migraines, whooping cough and pneumonia.The Government tells us to stay alert. So how can we help ourselves to see the wood from the trees It is always good to bear in mind the possibility of coronavirus but the symptom checklist below can help to provide you with a dferential diagnosis, as doctors call it, to pinpoint your problem.Prevention is always better than cure and the good news is that all the measures we ought to be taking to protect ourselves from coronavirus should also help reduce the risk of these winter bugs.Frequent hand-washing, wearing of masks, social distancing and cleaning hard surfaces with bleach will all help keep us healthier. Another of the most ­important things you can do, as winter approaches, is to book your flu jab.If we protect the most vulnerable people in society by making them immune to seasonal flu, we can protect all the others with whom they come into contact.That is why this winter the Government aims to immunise up to  million people — twice as many as usual. title: bbc wrong land hope glory rule brittania proms
story: The annual Last Night of the Proms concert at the Royal Albert Hall concert, beamed around the world, traditionally ends with the flag-waving anthems.But organisers of the BBC Proms said Land of Hope and Glory and Rule Britannia! would be featured as orchestral versions instead.This was reportedly because Finnish conductor Dalia Stasevska wanted them dropped due to their links to colonialism and slavery - claims she has now denied.A YouGov poll for The Times has found that  per cent oppose the BBC’s move with  per cent backing the broadcaster’s compromise.Just five per cent believe the songs should not be performed at all.The BBC’s decision was branded “idiotic” by former chairman Michael Grade who said it was “too trapped in the Westminster bubble”.The poll found that despite anger at its decision over the Proms, support for the BBC is holding up, with  per cent saying they view it favourably.It remains popular among younger people, women and Labour voters.But when it comes to funding,  per cent believe the BBC doesn’t provide value for money and  per cent think it should be funded through advertising.BBC has said the songs would be sung next year - and said the decision to cut the lyrics was over fears of a second wave of coronavirus.A spokesman said: “For the avoidance of any doubt, these songs will be sung next year.“We obviously share the disappointment of everyone that the Proms will have to be dferent but believe this is the best solution in the circumstances and look forward to their traditionalnext year.”Stasevska has herself strongly denied she had any role in deciding the format of the Last Night Of The Proms.The conductor said she was “honoured to be part of this years BBC Proms and its iconic Last Night” which she said was “incredibly exciting”.However, in recent days there has been a good deal of inaccurate speculation about my role in determining the format of this years Last Night Of The Proms,” the -year-old said.This  speculation has led to abuse and threats towards me and my family which is why I am speaking out.“For the record I have played no role in deciding the traditional elements of the programme, I recognise these are an important part of the event.“Ive been wrongly portrayed as a person who tries to influence political debates - this is not true. I am an artist, I want to be able to speak through my work to bring people together and build solidarity.”Meanwhile friends of Stasevska have come forward to say BBC bosses were behind the decision to drop the songs.They told the  she would not demand a change to the patriotic songs.One said: From Dalia’s point of view there has been a lot of unpleasantness and some of the stuff that has been written is heartbreaking.“It is frightening, unpleasant, scary stuff and she can’t say anything as she can’t be a part of any of that.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Heres what you need to know about the partys new leader.Sir Ed Davey is the leader of the Liberal Democrats, after being elected on August , .He beat challenger Layla Moran with , votes - double the amount she managed to get.Davey studied at Jesus College, Oxford, before doing a masters at Birkbeck University.In  he was defeated in his Kingston and Surbiton seat after  years as an MP, but won it back from the Conservatives in .Sir Ed was criticised by his leadership rival after he suggested his electoral strategy could decapitate that blonde head of Boris Johnson.After the criticism, Davey tweeted he regretted the use of violent language.He said: “I recognise this wasn’t an acceptable choice of phrase and I’m sorry.This was careless use of language, meant in electoral sense and in no way literally.While we should be robust in our opposition, we do have to carefully consider impact of our words and I failed to do that.Davey was knighted in the  New Years Honours for his dedication and commitment to political and public service.He was also sworn in as a member of the Privy Council of the United Kingdom on February , , giving him the Honoric Title The Right Honourable for le.In , he was also elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts.Sir Ed is quadrilingual - You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK is experiencing a jobs crisis. Mass redundancies are being announced with grim regularity, and I fear we will see more unless the government urgently changes course. The furlough scheme, a leline during the coronavirus crisis for many, is now being withdrawn from all businesses, whatever their circumstance. That blanket approach completely ignores that some sectors and regions have been much harder hit than others. Since August, employers have been required to pay for the pension and national insurance contributions of their furloughed staff. And in just three days, from September , employers across the country will also be required to pay % of the salary of their furloughed employees. That rule applies to all businesses across the board. Whether your business is trading well, whether it’s slowly recovering but still struggling, or whether it cannot operate properly or at all due to local lockdown restrictions, the furlough leline is being pulled away, come what may. It’s clearly illogical and unfair to treat every business in this unorm way. * What do you think  Do you agree  Have your say in the comments below Hospitality, retail and key manufacturing industries have been particularly hard hit by job losses, with thousands already announced and more predicted by trade bodies. Some businesses, such as night clubs, are still totally locked down. They are rightly following the public-health measures and are therefore unable to bring in any income, yet are being asked to paythey want to protect their employees’ jobs. The government is also failing to recognise that its approach could mean making this country more unequal with parts of the UK still under local lockdowns, and some areas of the UK having more of the businesses that have been worst affected by the crisis. It would be far better to be targeting those sectors that really need the help than offering £, to every business next February for every worker they take back off furlough. That policy means an awful lot of money is being spent on workers who would have been rehired anyway in sectors that are recovering after lockdown. Germany and France have schemes in place enabling workers to be put on part-time working and have the rest of their wage subsidised. Extended support, targeted at key sectors, could work in a similar way. The government has said they cannot save every job, but in taking this rigid approach, they are washing their hands of every livelihood still under threat. Plan to care  There’s been a % rise in the number of children needing foster care during this pandemic, and Labour has called for a proper plan from government to ensure children moving into the care system can access the support they need. On this week’s episode of my podcast Reasons to be Cheerful, we talk with the poet and writer Lemn Sissay about My Name is Why – his powerful memoir about growing up in the care system. Lemn talks about his -year battle to access his records and why it was so important to tell his story. Zombie horror  Boris Johnson this week blamed the A-level exam fiasco on a “mutant algorithm”. It does make you wonder whether this government will ever take responsibility for anything. He’d previously said the results system was “robust” as did Education Secretary Gavin Williamson. Distress was caused to so many young people, and the government can’t even say the buck stops with them. It feels much more a case of a zombie government than a mutant algorithm to me. Grants clawback will hit jobs    High streets across the country have been hit hard by this pandemic. We’ve seen waves of job losses from household names like MS, WH Smith, Pizza Express, John Lewis and Boots. And while retail sales overall are rebounding, sales at department stores and clothing shops are still down on pre-pandemic levels. More than a billion remains unused of the Government’s business grants funds, with many thousands of firms having been locked out of support. But the Business Secretary wants local councils tothat money by the end of the month. That can’t be right when so many firms are still struggling. Labour has called for that underspend to be turned into a Hospitality and High Streets Fightback Fund, with restrictions eased so more businesses can access the funding they need. Clawing that money back rather than redeploying it flexibly means ministers risk accelerating the jobs crisis. We must do everything we can to protect our country’s vital city centres and prevent shuttered high streets. Time to invest in going green    Climate change is a massive long-term threat to the country. To tackle the threat means we will need to change the way we power our homes, move around our towns and cities, and use our land. This may sound daunting and it is, but there is also a chance to ensure that in tackling that threat we can create a better economy and quality of le for people. That’s what I am determined we do as a country. Think of all the jobs that need doing, from insulating homes to building the zero carbon engines of the future to planting trees and creating green spaces that we can all enjoy. Britain can have a bright manufacturing futurewe take a lead in the environmentally friendly jobs of the future. It makes environmental and economic sense. At a time when we are facing an unemployment emergency, this is the moment to power forward with action to create those jobs we badly need. It’s what we have seen in other countries. Germany has already announced €bn worth of plans, with France likely also to invest a signicant amount. So far, the Government’s warm words on the need for a green recovery have not been matched by their deeds. The £bn of green investment announced pales in comparison. We owe it to ourselves to build back better, and we owe it to future generations to tackle the climate emergency. That’s why Labour has been talking to businesses, unions, workers, campaign groups and the public about ideas to kickstart a recovery that builds an environmentally sustainable economy with a zero carbon army of workers. We need a Green Recovery worthy of the name. Campaign aims to protect us all    Labour’s Jobs, Jobs, Jobs campaign aims to fight for jobs, keep workers safe and back businesses. Fight for jobs: by reforming the furlough scheme so it supports those in the worst-hit sectors and targets aid to struggling industries. Back our businesses: by setting up a fightback fund to prevent firms going under and save our high streets.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Tories have been accused of forcing people to choose between their jobs and their health ahead of a push to get more workers back in offices. Ministers have reportedly made doom-laden warnings that working from home could ultimately cost you your job, just in time for a major media campaign launch by the Government next week. The television and newspaper messages will promote the Governmentaposs aim to reduce the number of employees working from home amid fears that town and city centres are becoming ghost areas as workers stay away. But Thehas quoted a number of anonymous sources that go further than the economic argument, making claims working from home is tied to job cuts. The paper says one government source told them: People need to understand that working from home is not the benign option it seems. If they are only seeing workers once a fortnight then that could prove problematic for some employees in the future. “Suddenly the word ‘restructure’ is bandied about and people who have been working from home find themselves in the most vulnerable position.”  And an unnamed cabinet minister claimed companies would carry out productivity reviews when they realise some people aren’t working as hard as they thought. Neither source mentions that some companies may have actually saved money by reducing operating costs, while many employees will have financially gained by removing travel costs.  Labour has criticised theto work plans as being unconscionable while the CBI said anyto work push should involve a hybrid approach that did not force people to go back.Labouraposs shadow business minister Lucy Powell said: It beggars belief that the Government are threatening people like this during a pandemic. Forcing people to choose between their health and their job is unconscionable. Number  should condemn this briefing and categorically rule out any such campaign. Dame Carolyn Fairbairn, director-general of the CBI, said a hybrid approach with home and office working is the best way forward. Speaking to Times Radio on Thursday, Dame Carolyn said: This is not about compulsion. I couldnapost say that more strongly. This is about creating the opportunity and the confidence to get to a hybrid that gets the best of both worlds. Weaposre certainly not there yet. Our offices are at risk of dying. And we would regret that very muchwe allowed that to happen.

This Bank Holiday, the top temperatures could reach C in London while parts of Scotland will be chillier with highs of C, well below the average of c usually seen in the country. Heavy showers on Thursday brought major problems on the roads, with flash floods reported in parts of Surrey creating dficult driving conditions and road closures, while Belmont railway station was forced to shut. A yellow warning for heavy rain has been placed over north-east England which is expected to last until am on Friday, while thunderstorms are forecast in parts of southern England and South Wales between am and pm. However, throughout this time Government messaging has been confused and bungled.  The latest sht in Government messaging that happened last week was that they inferred they wanted to see more localised restrictions, ying them ward by ward rather than by local authority areas. To add to the confusion, Government want to review and change these place by place weekly, leading to inconsistency in restrictions across the North. In the latest guidance from Government there is a presumption that wards with a low number of cases will start to revert to the national restrictions this week.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSeven in  Brits think society has become less respectful over the past two years, according to new research. A survey of , adults found  per cent had seen someone screaming or shouting at another member of public in a retail store. Racist, sexist or homophobic abuse has been witnessed by  per cent while out shopping or walking. And one in  people had seen someone scream or shout at a member of staff in hospital. Two thirds now think the levels of disrespect in the UK have reached an unacceptable level - with  per cent feeling the problem has got worse in the last two years. But, while Brits say society is getting worse in terms of the abuse they see, three quarters has admitted dishing it out THEMSELVES. As many as  per cent of those polled said theyaposve disrespected someone in the past week alone, according to Nationwide Building Society. Of those whoaposve looked back on a moment and realised they had disrespected someone, more than halfsaid they were disappointed with themselves. While  per cent felt ashamed and  per cent said they were determined to do better in the future. The study also found emergency service workers topped a list of people who were not as valued as they should be in society. They were followed by teachers and education support staff, those who work on public transport, members of the armed forces and waiting staff. The survey also revealed how apostoxicapos the public think social media has become. More than three quarters think abuse online has reached unacceptable levels - with  per cent leaving social media due to abuse they or someone they know has suffered.  However, almost two thirds of adults feel they have become more respectful with age - but seven per cent admit to becoming less respectful. The research was carried out by Nationwide Building Society after it launched a three-year partnership to support The Football Associationaposs Respect campaign. The grassroots football initiative aims to reinforce the importance of mutual respect on and off the pitch. As part of the campaign, the FA will be advising parents and coaches on their roles in creating a fun, safe and inclusive environment for everyone.  Sara Bennison, Nationwide chief marketing officer, said:  has not been the year any of us expected - so much distress.But we have also had a sharp reminder of how dependent on each other we all are.Fostering greater mutual respect becomes more important than ever.The FA have demonstrated their commitment to this at a grassroots level and we are delighted to be able to help them expand their Respect programme. It is hoped the initiative will ensure a positive and enjoyable football environment for young people by promoting respect between players, coaches, referees and spectators. The campaign is looking to involve one million players, parents and coaches in The FA Respect programme over the next three years. James Kendall, director of football development at The FA, added: Over the years The FAaposs Respect campaign has championed the importance of mutual respect on and off the football pitch, most particularly amongst young people. We have worked hard to provide players with the guidance and confidence to act in this way the same is true for parents, referees and the communities they play within. It is so good then that we can work with partners such as Nationwide who understand the positive impact football can have on society and share our determination to improve the game. As we restart the grassroots game it is important to take the opportunity to reaffirm the values that are crucial for the wellbeing of football - respect and anti-discrimination are core to that.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe widow of slain PC Andrew Harper has pleaded for Mirror readers to back her campaign for mandatory le sentences anyone for who kills an emergency service hero, as she blasted the fact her husband’s killers could be free in as little as seven years. Lissie Harper admits she felt let down by jurors and wants those who take a le - like those who stole Andrew from her just just four weeks after their wedding day - to pay the price. “I’m not sure what happened to Andrew will ever sink in,” Lissie says. “It’s not really something that’s easy to come to terms with. Everything in my le is dferent now. “Yet it could be  years or less and those who did this to us could be out on the streets living the same sort of criminal lestyle. Whereas Andrew’s le has been robbed from him. It’s not right. And it’s despicable to think that is just how things are and we’ve accepted that for so long. To help Lissie’s campaign to protect our emergency services heroes and support Harper’s Law, sign the petition here.“It’s time to change that.” PC Harper was killed when teenage thugs dragged him with their speeding car for more than a mile. He was left with such “catastrophic injuries”, that one witness mistook his body for that of an injured deer. Devastated we Lissie, , was then dealt a further heartwrenching blow when the three teens responsible - Driver Henry Long, , and Jessie Cole and Albert Bowers, both  - were cleared of murder and sentenced for the lesser charge of manslaughter instead - meaning they could be back on the streets in as little as seven and eight years with time off for good behaviour. Now, after enduring what would have been her first wedding anniversary and the first anniversary of his death, Lissie wants to right these wrongs for her beloved Andrew. And ahead of meeting with Home Secretary Priti Patel next month, she’s asking Mirror readers to help back her petition for Harper’s Law, which will see anyone committing a crime which leads to the death of an emergency services worker get an automatic le sentence. Askedshe was angry towards the jurors , Lissie laments: “I feel very let down.  “Somehow they didn’t see what the whole rest of the country could see. “But I’m putting all my energy into Harper’s Law so that it doesn’t happen again, to someone .” Under her proposed lawany emergency services worker is killed as a direct consequence of crime, the offender should automatically spend the rest of their le in jail. This meansa firefighter is killed in an arson, the arsonist would face the ultimate sentence. Some may argue it’s a knee-jerk call for American-style “eye for an eye”, “string them up” justice. But Lissie, backed by the Police Federation of England and Wales, stresses it’s about valuing those who put their lives on the line every day.  “When it comes to justice, America’s a whole dferent kind of world. And that’s the reason we doing Harper’s Law - to balance out what’s right and what should be,” she explains. “The death sentence is a very, very dferent thing altogether and that’s not what this is about but obviously I want there to be much tougher convictions. “If you take someone’s le, that’s it - pure and simple - you should pay for that. If you’re committing a crime and as a result of that crime someone is killed I think you deserve to spend the rest of your le in prison.” She adds that her husband would be right behind her: “I know that he would be very supportive of Harper’s Law. Supportive is not all he’d be. “He’d also be surprised,” Lissie admits.  “All this is not something I’d done before.” That’s an understatement. Lissie was once so timid about public speaking, she had a friend read out her wedding speech. Now she’s speaks with great dignity. She knows her campaign inside out, she shares stories of how content and happy she and Andrew were, and is an open book when it comes to the dficulty she’s had coping with the grief. What happened on that fateful night of August  last year caused national outrage.  The childhood sweethearts, who had dated since they were  and grew up in each others’ pockets, had celebrated their fairytale wedding at Oxfordshire’s Ardington House on July . They had their compact-but-homely one-bed cottage on the banks of the Thames in Wallingford, South Oxfordshire, a stone’s throw from their families. And they were planning to start a family of their own after a belated honeymoon to the Males, planned for just a few days later. But with one  call that all disappeared. Committed Thames Valley police officer PC Harper was four hours into overtime. At pm he rang Lissie to say he loved her and talk about her planned new design business.  Then just before he was due to sign off, a call came in about a stolen quad bike in Stanford Dingley, Berkshire. As PC Harper tried to stop the thieves they sped off in their Seat Toledo, while his feet were caught in a tow rope hanging out of its car boot. His fatal injuries left him so unrecognisible, Lissie was warned not to go to the morgue. Her heartache was only compounded at trial when Long, Cole and Bowers, petty criminals from a travellers’ community in nearby Reading were found not guilty of murder. Instead Long pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was sentenced to  years while the others were found guilty of the same charge and sentenced to  years each. With good behaviour they could all be out in half that time.  “It wasn’t what I expected” says Lissie. “I just felt disappointed for Andrew. That’s all I could think about. How could these people take so much le and that’s what they’re faced with  It’s just not right. It’s outrageous.” Lissie already has , signatures on her Harper’s Law petition with Change.org. Petitions have to be discussed by parliamentthey reach ,. But Lissie wants more to ensure her upcoming crunch meeting with Priti Patel goes well. She says: “I would really appreciate the Mirror‘s loyal readers adding their voice to my vital campaign by signing my petition. And together we will achieve Harper’s Law.” Police alone face , physical attacks a year.  And there’s a certain irony, that one of Andrew’s only bugbears about his dream job was the soft justice his collars sometime got. “Andrew loved his job,” she says. “But police spend a lot of time out on the streets, trying to arrest people and get the right type of justice, only for them not get the sentence that they should.” Andrew’s family are backing Lissie all the way. She’s still and always will be, part of the family. But Lissie’s also under no illusion Harper’s Law is one of the only things helping her get out of bed in the mornings. She spent nine months living with her parents after Andrew’s death and only ed to their cottage in May. Andrew and her had planned to be hearing the little pitter patter of tiny feet by now.  Instead she woke on their wedding anniversary in July to see his toothbrush still in its holder, his clothes still in the wardrobe, but only his ashes in a wooden box for company. As for a baby, well, that’s now her campaign. That poignant date was obviously horrendous. “Oh yeah,” she says slowly. “I went for a walk and I got him some flowers and just remembered the happy memories we had from our wedding day. But, yeah it was hard.” Has she brought herself to watch the wedding video yet  “No, no, not yet. I think I will one day, but no I just can’t,” she says. Nor can she get rid of any of his belongings. Or picture moving out of the cottage. And whether she could one day marry again is not even a seed of a thought.  The anniversary of his death was just as tough. “It was the same pain as every other day, just more signicant,” she says. “I did all I could do - had a quiet day remembering him. I still can’t believe it’s been a year.” Does she still think about the what s  “A little bit,” she admits. “He told me once ‘Death is just another adventure’. There’s definitely comfort in that.” Lissie has had some positive news recently in that the offenders’ sentences are to be reviewed by the Attorney General who felt they are too lenient.

Tesco has announced a handy scheme for any customer who arrive at its stores without a face mask or face covering. Tesco previously confirmed it would be creating signage to remind customers to don them. But Tesco and the three other supermarket giants said they would not make staff police the new law, which came into effect a month ago, on July . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Toriesapos meagre £-a-day self-isolation benefit would cover just five minutes with Boris Johnsonaposs new personal trainer,can reveal. The Prime Ministeraposs aposperformance coachapos Harry Jameson charges an eye-watering £-an-hour, the equivalent of £. a minute. It is in stark contrast to the paltry amount being offered by the government to low-income workers who need to self-isolate in high-risk areas. These iniduals will be able to claim £ for a -day periodthey test positive for Covid-, although critics say the sum is nowhere near enough to live on. Mr Johnsonaposs new trainer is quoted as charging an hourly rate of £ on the website of the luxurious Rosewood London hotel, where he is reportedly the apospersonal trainer in residenceapos. The Rosewood also offers a £, deal called aposThe Jameson Retreatapos, which covers a two-night stay at the hotel and daily training sessions with the man himself.  Iniduals eligible for the governmentaposs new self-isolation benefit will receive just a fraction of this princely sum. The Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham said the £-a-day payment leaves people without enough to live on, while a Labour politician one of the local lockdown areas described it as a aposslap in the faceapos. Mr Burnham said: It’s good the Government has at last acknowledged the problem of people who can’t afford to self-isolate. But this sadly isn’t the solution. It leaves people without enough to live on. We need a scheme like Jury Service where wages are covered. Although workers can still claim statutory sick pay, Universal Credit and Working Tax Credits on top of the benefit, many believe it is still not enough.Mr Burnham added: “The health secretary has already said that he couldn’t live on statutory sick payat £ a week. So how can an announcement like this work ” Mohammed Iqbal, Labour leader of Pendle Borough Council in Lancashire, told BBC Radio ’s Today programme: The figures that the Government have introduced are really a slap in the face for those people who sadly test positive and there is no incentive in my opinion for those people to self-isolate.  If you’re a manual worker who’s not able to do their job from home, normally getting paid the living wage or the minimum wage, the Government are now going to say to you we’ll pay you £. an hour. Not acceptable. However, Health Secretary Matt Hancock today argued £-a-day is enough when combined with other benefits, despite it taking weeks to claim Universal Credit. He acknowledged that some people are losing out on their income from not being able to work, adding that the payment is aposset at the level of statutory sick pay in order to make sure people don’t lose out from doing the right thingapos.  Mr Hancock said: We are introducing it in Oldham and Pendle and Blackburn with Darwen in the first instance. These are the areas in the country where the rates are the highest and we have the highest level of intervention, the strongest local lockdownyou like. And we’ll roll that out from next week and then obviously monitor it very closely and of course we speak to all of these people through NHS Test and Trace.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA luxury hotel will soon open in England which allows guests to sleep just metres away from roaming giraffes. Dubbed the first of its kind in the western hemisphere, Port Lympne Hotel  Reserve near Hythe, Kent has spent nearly two years preparing to open its Giraffe Hall for animal lovers. Located inside a th century Grade II listed Wealden hall house, the hotel boasts  en-suite bedrooms, and an additional five luxury cabins - which will provide  mile unrivalled views over the reserve. Giraffe Hall is at the top of the reserve, overlooking The African Experience, meaning guests will be closer than ever to animals commonly only seen in the wild. A statement from Port Lympne says: Once completed, the hotel will offer a luxury safari feel while incorporating the comforts and décor of an English stately home. Guests will be able to feed the giraffes from their bedroom windows, while thereaposs also going to be a cabana style retreat for visitors to sit and enjoy a drink and take in the views. The surrounding gardens are also being tended to, where a route for giraffes is being made. Families will be able to get a good nightaposs rest and be woken up by the beautul giraffes whose long walking trail will be directed right past the building. A total of  guests can stay at the hotel at any one time. Itaposs expected the luxury hotel will open next summer. Port Lympne says the interiors will be designed by Victoria Aspinall and that many of the buildingaposs original outstanding features will be retained. The house will convert the already on-site restaurant to include an outdoor decking and offer breakfast, lunch and dinner. According to reports, the waiting list to stay at the hotel has more than , people on it.The animals have already been introduced to their wider habitat, and many of them are already walking past the under construction property, Kent Live reported last September. Port Lympne has previously spoken about its plans to make Giraffe Hall a sought after venue for wedding and private parties. No price package has yet been published due to the incompletion of the animal experience.  Port Lympne already offers a number of animal experiences, including Lion Lodge, Rhino Lodge and Tiger Lodge. Guests staying at Lion Lodge sleep just metres away from the lions - Adras, Oudrika and their three cubs - and right in the centre of their natural and spacious habitat. The lodge includes picture windows in both the master bedroom and the open plan living area, meaning guests will be just a whisker away from lions.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA family-of-five were left with horric burns after a hot water tap explosion sparked a devastating house fire. Four of the family were placed in medically-induced comas after a blast at their holiday home in Torres Vedras, Portugal, left them fighting for their lives. Mafalda Da Silva Baptista, , from Switzerland, has described how her aposheroapos brother, then aged nine, ran back into the property to rescue her on April , . Pedro Baptista, , Fatima Da Silva, , Diogo Da Silva Baptista,  and Tozé Da Silva, , all suffered first to third-degree burns.  The horror fire happened after a hot water tap in the home exploded when her dad Pedro switched it on. Mafalda, then seven, woke up to a fire surrounding her room and feared for her le as she was too scared to run through the flames. Realising she was still in the house, Mafalda’s brother, Diogo, who was nine-years-old at the time, rushed in to to save her, They then fled to their neighbour’s home as Mafalda saw her father jump out of the kitchen window. Her dad was engulfed in flames after his clothes caught fire.  Mafalda and her cousin took a cold shower at a neighbour’s house and recalled trembling and feeling her skin tighten up.  The whole family, apart from Diogo, were placed in medically-induced comas, with doctors giving them a  per cent chance to survive. Tozé, who lost half his ear and several fingers on his right hand, stayed in a coma for a month, while the rest of the family woke up after two weeks.  Speaking about the terrying moment, Mafalda said: “I went on vacation to Portugal with my father, brother, aunt, and my cousin. “We had a newly built house while my mother stayed in Switzerland to work. “In the morning I was with my brother in bed sleeping when our house exploded. “It happened when my father wanted to turn on the warm water.  “I woke up from the heat and saw fire everywhere, I was standing like a statue and I didnapost dare to run through the fire. “My brother was my hero. He came back into the house because he noticed that I was still inside. He came in and took my hand and we ran out to the neighbours together. “My aunt and my cousin were already in front of the door. “I looked around to see my father and saw him jumping out of the kitchen window, his whole body and clothes were burning. “We ran to one neighbour and my father to the other.  “I just realised how serious the situation was when I was under the cold shower with my two-year-old cousin. “I started to tremble and my skin began to pull together. At that moment we all felt no pain because the fear was greater than the pain and the fear of death.” Mafalda remained at the hospital for more than a year and spent two months at a rehabilitation clinic to gain her mobility back. She had dficulty accepting her new appearance and was ridiculed and bullied by her peers at school.  The teenager said: “After the accident, it was dficult because I stayed in the hospital for a very long time and my le had completely changed. “I looked very dferent, and couldnapost care less about myself and didnapost love myself. “I was in the hospital for a year and when I came back to school, I was heavily bullied. “I was told things like ‘ugly burned chicken’ and ‘here comes the burned cowapos.”  Over the years, Mafalda has learned to love herself from within and is grateful for all the struggles she has faced in her le saying it has shaped her into the person she is today. She said: “Today I am so thankful for everything! I am immensely grateful for all the dficulties I had in my le, because I think back and know how strong I was and that I always fought. “I love myself very tightly and nobody can take that away from me. “This accident was a blessing for me.  “I was allowed to see and learn a lot and I am very grateful for every problem and every pain. My past defines the woman that I am today.” Mafalda hopes to become a model and is proud of her scars, seeing the beauty in her skin as a symbol of her strength. She added: “I want to show the world that everything can be achieved in le! “I would like to become a photo model, evenmany people doubt my dream, but I believe in myself.

story: A prestigious art show is set to arrive in Aberdeen after councillors approved funding to bring the event to the north-east.The British Art Showis an influential exhibition of contemporary art and is showcased in four cities around the country every five years.Aberdeen will host part of next year#s event # along with Manchester, Wolverhampton and Plymouth # after the city council#s strategic commissioning committee approved £, to bring it to the newly-refurbished art gallery.The ninth edition of the exhibition, named BAS, will be held between July  and October  , and forms part of the city#s Event calendar of events # as well as being a key component of the council#s socio-economic recovery plan for the next two years.The team at the art gallery are set to work with VisitAberdeenshire and VisitScotland in the lead-up to the event.Council culture spokeswoman Marie Boulton said: “The British Art Show is only held every five years therefore it is a real coup for Aberdeen Art Gallery to land such a prestigious exhibition. story: An Aberdeen pharmacist has spoken of his hopes that CCTV will help catch a masked raider who broke into the store he manages.The culprit used a blunt object to smash his way into the Brian A Christie pharmacy in Bucksburn, leaving the glass front door shattered.He stole a few items from the shop yesterday before making his getaway in a beige car driven by a woman.Andrew Wilson, superintendent pharmacist, manages the store along with two others in Aberdeenshire.He described the incident as “unfortunate” but he was relieved that no expensive items were stolen.He said: #It#s unfortunate to see this happen but it is an aspect of our job because we sell such high-value items.#It looks like the person has smashed through the front door with an object like a hammer, as there was glass everywhere this morning.#The alarm went off as soon as he broke in, with police arriving on the scene within ten minutes, so the person was not in the pharmacy for very long.#We#ve got quite extensive CCTV in operation at the pharmacy, so the police will be using that and hopefully the man is tracked down very soon.”The early morning raid took place just before am, with the police arriving on scene about ten minutes after the incident took place.It is believed the man tried to gain entry to the pharmacy via the rear entrance but failed and instead targeted the glass front door.Mr Wilson labelled the crime “opportunistic” as the thief did not seem to target anything in particular.He said: #My initial reaction towards this is that it was an opportunistic crime, as it wasn#t a focused attack, it was a smash and grab.#If they had planned this, they would have tried to grab the more expensive items, such as the controlled and subscribed drugs.#A big police presence were seen at the scene for about three hours as they undertook forensic investigations.The shop reopened at pm once staff had the chance to get reorganised.It is not known what items were stolen.Mr Wilson added: #I got woken up by a phone call today at about  past six by the pharmacy#s key holder which was a bit like a rude awakening.#I can only assume they tried to break in under cover of darkness but then again at  am the sun is starting to come up so it is a strange time to try it.”Police are currently investigating the incident.Inspector Graeme Penny, from Bucksburn Police Station, said: “Around am on Thursday,  officers were called to the Sclattie Park area of Aberdeen, following a break-in to a pharmacy, which took place shortly beforehand.#Inquiries have established that the suspect was a man, who was seen leaving the area in a beige coloured car, being driven by a woman.#Anyone with information, who witnessed the break-in take place or saw the suspects leaving the scene, title: first phase of development at aberdeen business park complete
story: The first phase of a new development at an Aberdeen business park is now complete.Property firm Ryden announced the completion of the first phase of the new development at ABZ Business Park in Dyce, which consists of nine new business units totalling , sq ft.The construction of the second phase will begin shortly and will see the development of a further six units of , sq ft.ABZ Business Park offers fully-serviced sites for office, industrial and hotel development and overlooks Aberdeen International Airport.Surrounding occupiers include Noble Drilling, Bowtech Teledyne, Ethos Energy Ltd, Global Energy Group, Aramark, SPX International, Crown Plaza and the Holiday Inn.Paul Richardson from Ryden said: #This is a superb development in an excellent location overlooking Aberdeen Airport.#The premises have been built to a high specication and it is not surprising that we have had such strong interest despite challenging market conditions It is positive news that ABZ Developments Ltd will be pressing ahead with the second phase of the development.#We feel confident we will continue to attract the right businesses to this new development at ABZ Business Park.#Tim Stevenson of ABZ Developments Ltd. added: #Completing the first phase of this development is an important milestone in our multi let scheme.#We are delighted to note that we have concluded the letting of three of the initial nine units in recent weeks and are in detailed discussions with other interested parties.#In light of the positive interest levels we have now instructed our contractor MTM Construction to proceed with the second phase of the development and look forward to its completion in early .#Property developer GSS Developments received conditional approval for the building of  industrial units at ABZ Business Park in May .GSS was required to demonstrate a link to nearby public transport, implement a green travel plan to move people away from the use of cars and the carrying title: support for north east families considering adoption
story: Families considering adoption will be able to access continuing local authority support.Aberdeenshire Council#s education and children#s services committee heard how a targeted campaign between  and  had led to an increase in the number of families adopting children.Eight families adopted in the two-year period, double the number between  and . Two ed for a second adoption, while one fostering family also adopted a child in their care.The number of inquiries about adoption also rose by  to  in .Families are given continuing support from the local authority, while those who have been adopted also have the option of keeping in touch with their birth families through the council#s Letterbox scheme.Rosemary Bruce, vice-chair of the committee, said: “Our adoption service has every right to be proud of what it has achieved.
